Organization Description: Albertsons is one of the largest U.S. grocery chains, with ~2,270 stores across 34 states. It offers full-service grocery, pharmacy, fuel, and e-commerce through banners like Safeway and Vons. The company emphasizes private-label products and loyalty programs to drive margins. Annual revenue is approximately $72B with profit around $1.6B.

Founded in 1924, the AHA leads efforts to combat heart disease and stroke through research, public health campaigns, and training. It has funded over $5 billion in cardiovascular research to date. The association publishes widely used clinical guidelines and advocates for healthy living and public policy. It operates with more than 35 million volunteers and donors nationwide.

Baylor is a private Baptist-affiliated R1 research university in Waco, TX, established in 1845. It offers over 140 undergraduate and graduate majors, and champions Christian-based education. Enrollment is ~20,000 students, and athletics play a significant role in campus life. The university has a growing footprint in community service and global health research.

Bridge Builders is a Dallas-based nonprofit that mends racial and socioeconomic divides through mentorship, events, and networking. It engages ~200 volunteers annually to support youth, families, and community leaders. The organization operates under Christian principles, providing mediation and development services. Reported revenue is approximately $1.7 million.

CPAL is a Dallas-based nonprofit focused on reducing child poverty by 50% by 2040 through evidence-based policy solutions. It works in five key areas: maternal health, public benefits, housing stability, public safety, and early childhood. CPAL partners with local governments and nonprofits to test and scale impactful interventions. Its work is rooted in rigorous data analysis and systems thinking.

The City of Dallas is the municipal government managing public health, social services, and community initiatives for 1.3 million residents. Agencies under its umbrella include public health, housing, sustainability, and economic development. It oversees city-run food distribution events and nutrition programs. Budget priorities reflect health equity and food access in underserved neighborhoods.

Community Foundations Texas is an association of over 50 community foundations statewide, promoting local philanthropy and leadership. It offers shared resources, advocacy, and capacity-building training. Members award millions in local grants annually across education, health, and civic projects. The network engages donors and nonprofit leaders across Texas.

Crossroads Community Services provides food assistance and support services to low-income families in Dallas. It operates a client-choice pantry model and collaborates with social service providers for wraparound support. The organization also engages in research to improve hunger relief methods. It serves tens of thousands of individuals annually through partnerships and direct services.

Dallas County governs county-wide services, including health care, criminal justice, and public assistance programs. It administers food access efforts via county clinics, SNAP outreach, and community centers. The county budget supports nutrition education and mobile health units in low-income areas. Population served exceeds 2.6 million residents.

Organization Name: Dallas County Health and Human Services
Organization Description: DC HHS is the county’s health department responsible for disease surveillance, healthcare access, and social services. It conducts community clinics, immunizations, and nutrition programs targeting vulnerable populations. The department coordinates with nonprofits to address food insecurity. It also tracks health outcomes and disparities data.

The Dallas Hospital Council represents ~35 hospitals and healthcare systems in Dallas County. It coordinates clinical collaborations, emergency preparedness, and community health planning. The group advocates for hospital-related legislation and funding. It also leads data-sharing initiatives and workforce development programs.

The Dallas Morning News is one of Texas’s oldest and most influential newspapers, founded in 1885 and serving the DFW metroplex. It provides reporting on local news, policy, health, education, and food access—shaping public opinion and civic dialogue. Through its editorial board and investigative journalism, it holds institutions accountable and highlights equity issues. It also partners with local nonprofits for awareness campaigns and community reporting.

This Texas-based nonprofit advocates for the rights of small farmers and homesteaders, focusing on fair food policies and local control. It works to protect small producers from overly burdensome regulations. The alliance engages in legislative lobbying, legal advocacy, and grassroots organizing. It also provides resources and alerts to help farmers navigate changing policies.

Farm Vet is a veterinary supply company that supports farmers and ranchers with livestock health products and on-farm service referrals. It offers pharmaceuticals, equipment, and animal nutrition solutions tailored for agricultural clients. The company aims to maintain herd health and productivity through preventative care. It also supports education around sustainable animal husbandry practices.

Green City Growers is an urban agriculture company specializing in hydroponic and aquaponic farming in reclaimed city spaces. It grows leafy greens and herbs for local retailers, hospitals, and schools. The business emphasizes sustainability and reduced food miles. It also educates communities on closed-loop farming and climate-resilient food systems.

Groundwork DFW is part of the national Groundwork USA network focused on urban revitalization and environmental justice. In Dallas, it supports green space creation, urban gardens, and youth employment through environmental stewardship. The organization works in underserved neighborhoods to increase access to healthy food and outdoor spaces. Its projects often involve community design, education, and sustainability goals.

GROW North Texas connects growers, communities, and organizations to improve food access and equity in North Texas. It runs programs for gleaning, backyard gardening, farm-to-school, and food rescue. The organization supports local farmers while also facilitating emergency food distribution. It also leads educational initiatives around nutrition and food systems.

HEB is a major Texas-based supermarket chain renowned for high-quality fresh produce, particularly regional products like Central Market. With over 400 stores, it supports communities through disaster relief, scholarships, and local partnerships. The company is privately owned and consistently ranks well for customer loyalty and employee engagement. It reinvests profits into innovation, including automated distribution centers.

Lyda Hill Holdings is a private investment firm and philanthropic office supporting science, nature, health, and community impact. Based in Dallas, it uses both grants and investments to catalyze innovation in fields like biotech, conservation, and urban resilience. The organization prioritizes evidence-based projects with scalable solutions. It often collaborates with nonprofits, research institutions, and entrepreneurs.

The Meadows Foundation is one of Texas's largest private philanthropies, headquartered in Dallas and focused on improving the quality of life for Texans. It funds initiatives in education, health, public safety, arts, and civic engagement. Since 1948, it has awarded more than $1.5 billion in grants. It also offers nonprofit capacity-building and leadership development programs.

Moonshot Compost is a Dallas-based company that collects food waste from homes, businesses, and institutions to create compost. It helps reduce landfill use and regenerate soil for urban agriculture. The company partners with schools and farms to promote sustainable practices. It also tracks and reports diversion metrics for clients to encourage zero-waste efforts.

The North Texas Food Bank (NTFB) is the region’s largest hunger-relief organization, distributing food across 13 counties. It supplies partner pantries, shelters, and soup kitchens with nutritious food and meals. The food bank also runs mobile pantry events and SNAP outreach. It serves over 700,000 people annually and focuses on food equity and health outcomes.

Pan African Connection is a cultural center, bookstore, and event space in South Dallas focused on celebrating African heritage and promoting economic empowerment. It serves as a hub for local Black-owned businesses, community events, and educational programming. The organization connects cultural identity with community development. It frequently hosts food, art, and wellness initiatives with a Pan-African focus.

Parkland Health is the county’s primary safety-net hospital system, operating the historic Parkland Memorial Hospital. It delivers trauma care, specialty clinics, and community wellness programs to underserved populations. With over 10,000 employees, it manages outpatient clinics and newborn care. Parkland also provides essential nutrition and social support services within its facilities.

Paul Quinn is a private HBCU in Dallas known for social justice and community engagement programs. It operates the WE Over Me Farm, integrating student leadership with sustainable agriculture. Enrollment is ~1,300 undergraduates, and emphasis is on urban renewal and workforce development. The college fosters student-run food initiatives and local entrepreneurship.

Restorative Farms is an urban agriculture nonprofit focused on creating job pathways and improving health in food-insecure Dallas neighborhoods. It runs a local farm and seedling operation that provides produce and training for young adults and returning citizens. The organization blends farming, entrepreneurship, and education. Produce is sold through CSA boxes and local outlets.

SMU is a private, nonsectarian research university in Dallas with ~12,000 students. It excels in business, law, arts, sciences, and engineering, with over $100 million in annual research expenditures. SMU works closely with Dallas nonprofits on community education and health initiatives. Its Cox School of Business and Meadows School of the Arts are nationally recognized.

The South Dallas Employment Project is a collaborative initiative aimed at improving employment outcomes in historically underserved neighborhoods. It works with employers, schools, and social service providers to create job pathways. The project emphasizes wraparound supports like childcare, transportation, and housing to help participants maintain employment. It also facilitates skills training and job placement partnerships.

Sunwest Communications (founded 1982, Dallas, TX) is a strategic public relations and public affairs firm specializing in reputation management, crisis communications, CSR, and digital services. It serves corporate, nonprofit, government, and association clients, delivering campaigns that build visibility, credibility, and audience engagement. With 40+ years of experience and ~11–50 employees, it emphasizes tailored storytelling and media strategy.

The Texas Restaurant Association is a nonprofit trade group for restaurant operators statewide. It provides advocacy, training, and advisory services, and monitors legislative/regulatory issues affecting the hospitality industry. Its membership includes thousands of independent and chain operators. Revenue is primarily from dues, event sponsorships, and training programs.

United Way is a global nonprofit network that mobilizes communities to advance education, financial stability, and health. United Way of Metropolitan Dallas supports over 200 local partners and initiatives through fundraising, volunteer mobilization, and grantmaking. It leads collective impact programs across North Texas, especially in underserved communities. Its funding model includes workplace giving, corporate partnerships, and foundation support.

UTD is a public R1 university in Richardson, part of the UT system, with ~30,000 students. It’s known for STEM, computer science, and business programs, with strong industry partnerships. The university supports local food system research and community health projects. UTD also hosts labs focused on data-driven urban policy.

UT Southwestern is a leading academic medical center in Dallas, renowned for biomedical research, clinical care, and education. It operates multiple hospitals and outpatient clinics serving the regional population. Ranked among top US institutions for neurology, cardiology, and cancer treatment. The medical center is a center of innovation receiving substantial NIH funding.

IBM is a global technology and consulting firm that partners with retailers and nonprofits to implement enterprise solutions. It offers services ranging from data analytics and AI to supply chain optimization. IBM works with food banks and governments on digitization and transparency in distribution. Its technologies are used for improving logistics, fundraising analytics, and impact measurement.

Faith Commons promotes interfaith dialogue and civic engagement among religious communities in North Texas. It hosts panels, workshops, and advocacy campaigns focused on social justice, equity, and compassion. The organization partners with nonprofits and faith leaders to respond to current events and policy debates. It works to bridge ideological divides through shared moral values and public theology.

Allyn Media (founded 1983, Dallas, TX) is a women-owned full-service communications firm specializing in public relations, public affairs, political media, crisis management, and nonprofit development. It supports Fortune 500 companies, government, and grassroots clients with data-driven strategy, creative design, and coalition building. Known for award-winning campaigns in social justice, it blends brand strategy, advertising, and digital content services.

Timberview Farmstead is a nonprofit teaching farm in Fort Worth, Texas, built on a former golf course, that provides hands-on farm-based education, culinary experiences, and community programming. The campus includes greenhouses, a pavilion, gardens, and livestock areas, hosting field trips, camps, workshops, memberships, and private events with an emphasis on the themes “learn, grow, belong.” Their mission focuses on empowering young people and families through restorative agriculture, with plans to expand into social enterprises like a farm store, restaurant, health clinic, and agriscience academy.
Dallas Urban Farms establishes rooftop and backyard gardens to grow fresh produce sustainably within city limits.
The Dallas College program teaches urban agriculture techniques like hydroponics and habitat conservation to students and the broader community.
City of Dallas Sanitation Services handles residential waste collection recycling and roll-cart services citywide.
Community Waste Disposal operates North Texas residential and commercial trash and recycling hauling with eco-friendly CNG trucks.
Republic Services provides scheduled residential and commercial waste pickup recycling dumpster rentals and landfill management around Dallas.
This center delivers weekly groceries and hot meals to low-income families in South Dallas.
Oak Cliff Veggie Project grows fresh produce and educates residents on cultivation and cooking in South Dallas.
USDA’s Dallas Urban Service Center supports urban farmers with loans technical assistance and conservation programs.
Lavon Farms supplies fresh seasonal produce to local markets and restaurants via conventional farming in the region.
Jacob’s Reward Farm produces a variety of fruits and vegetables sold at Dallas-area farmers markets and grocery outlets.
Lucky Layla Farms grows mixed seasonal vegetables for sale to markets restaurants and wholesalers in North Texas.
Oba Farms offers whole goats lambs pasture chickens and beef for home slaughter and delivery around Dallas.
Stout Creek Farm raises grass‑fed beef pasture‑raised poultry lamb pork and eggs for sale at local farmers markets.
JBar Cattle is a family‑owned ranch supplying grass‑fed beef to the Dallas–Houston region.
Society Bakery & Tea Room produces scratch‑made cupcakes cakes and pastries and hosts afternoon tea in Dallas.
Cake Bar Dallas crafts southern-style scratch cakes pound cakes cookies and quick breads from its brick‑and‑mortar shop.
Lubellas Patisserie is an East Dallas handcrafted bakery offering cakes tarts macarons quiches and artisan breads.
White Rock Creamery produces small-batch artisan cheese and cream products using locally sourced milk.
Texas Dairyland processes and bottles fresh dairy products for distribution across Dallas-area retailers.
Greenhill Creamery transforms local milk into yogurt butter and specialty cheese for farmers markets and grocery stores.
Wagyu Ranch of Texas raises premium wagyu cattle and operates an on-site butchery processing for direct-to-consumer beef cuts.
Long Prairie Meats is a regional slaughterhouse and butchery serving Dallas-area restaurants and specialty grocers.
Andrews Meat Company supplies custom-cut meats and processing services to restaurants grocers and institutions in North Texas.
DFW Processing Plant handles large-scale food processing packaging and distribution for regional manufacturers.
Texas Protein Corporation processes meat and poultry products for wholesale retail and food service customers.
American Foods Group operates a meat processing and packing facility serving suppliers and grocers in the Dallas area.
Central Texas Food Transport delivers refrigerated produce and frozen goods throughout Dallas‑Fort Worth.
DLS offers cold-chain food transport and distribution solutions to restaurants grocers and food manufacturers locally.
DFW Food Express provides temperature-controlled and dry freight logistics for food service and retail clients across North Texas.
Tom Thumb is a regional grocery chain offering a wide selection of fresh produce deli bakery and household essentials.
Fiesta Mart is a multicultural supermarket chain specializing in Hispanic and international foods produce and meat.
Trader Joe’s offers a curated grocery shopping experience with unique private label goods and fresh produce.
Kroger operates large-format supermarkets in Dallas with full-service deli pharmacy and extensive produce and meat aisles.
Walmart Supercenter carries groceries alongside general merchandise electronics and home goods under one roof.
Costco offers bulk groceries fresh produce and household items to members at their Dallas warehouse locations.
Sam’s Club serves Dallas-area shoppers with wholesale bulk food produce meat and prepared meals for members.
BJ’s Wholesale Club supplies bulk groceries for members including fresh meats dairy and pantry staples.
7-Eleven operates Dallas-area convenience stores with grab‑and‑go snacks beverages and quick supermarket essentials.
Circle K stocks fuel snacks beverages and ready‑to‑eat items at many Dallas metro locations.
RaceTrac includes a wide range of grab‑and‑go foods and beverages alongside fuel services in Dallas-area stations.
Metrocrest runs a community food bank in northwest Dallas County to support food insecure families.
Harvest House collects stores and distributes food to Dallas families in crisis.
Sysco supplies foodservice wholesalers and retailers in Dallas with broad-line food and kitchen supplies.
US Foods delivers food products kitchen equipment and supplies to Dallas-area restaurants and institutional customers.
Performance Foodservice distributes food and related products to restaurants schools and care facilities in North Texas.
Pecan Lodge is a famed BBQ joint in Dallas known for Texas-style brisket ribs and southern comfort sides.
Uchi offers high-end Japanese sushi and modern Asian cuisine in Dallas’s Uptown neighborhood.
Mi Cocina is a Dallas-based Tex-Mex chain serving classic regional favorites with a contemporary twist.
UT Southwestern is a major medical and research university offering programs in medicine nursing and allied health.
Dallas College offers associate degrees technical training and urban agriculture education across multiple Dallas campuses.
Local Chef John Smith offers personal culinary services pop-up dinners and community cooking workshops in Dallas.
Ana Gonzalez is a Dallas-area grower who sells seasonal vegetables and herbs at local farmers markets.
Marcus Lee manages rooftop hives in Dallas harvesting and selling raw honey and offering pollinator workshops.
Located in east Dallas this pantry provides free groceries and emergency food support to local families in need.
This pantry in Dallas suburb Frisco distributes food boxes and support for families dealing with food insecurity.
Serving Irving and Dallas-area residents this pantry provides free food hygiene items and referrals.
Texas Health operates acute care hospitals and health services across Dallas with community outreach and wellness programs.
JPMorgan Chase’s Dallas headquarters offers banking services corporate philanthropy and financial literacy initiatives.
USPS Dallas center processes and distributes mail and packages supporting regional logistics and postal services.
Waste Management Inc. operates trash and recycling collection fleets servicing Dallas residences and businesses.
GFL Environmental picks up and hauls residential and commercial waste and recyclables throughout Dallas County.
Republic Services runs collection routes and waste hauling for residential commercial and industrial clients.
Earthwise Composting collects organic waste from Dallas businesses and residents to produce nutrient-rich compost.
Texas Compost Company processes yard trimmings and food scraps into compost for agriculture and landscaping in North Texas.
Green Dallas Composting offers curbside and drop-off organic waste collection services and community compost education.

White Rock Center of Hope runs a robust food pantry that distributes roughly 275,000–440,000 pounds of groceries annually to around 500 low-income East Dallas families each month, helping stave off hunger and food insecurity. They offer service by appointment across five zip codes and lean on a volunteer-powered model—including neighborhood food drives and twice-monthly drive‑through distributions—to meet this critical need.

A Black-owned grocery store in South Dallas, originally Save U More, now operating as Food Basket after acquisition. It fills a local food desert by providing fresh groceries and revitalizing a community resource.

Dallas-based nonprofit founded in 2004 offering food pantries, fresh produce partnerships, furniture, after-school & summer programs, and financial/housing assistance to families facing poverty and homelessness.

Major Dallas anti-poverty nonprofit—distributes ~3 million lbs of groceries annually (incl. 400k+ meals for kids), operates a client-choice pantry, housing, health, workforce & advocacy programs, serving ~50,000 people/year.

Provides 24/7 emergency shelter, comprehensive services (food, child care, education, employment support) to families with children experiencing homelessness in Dallas‑Collin counties, helping them transition to stable housing.

Administers ARPA‑funded nutrition & food infrastructure grants in Texas—including emergency food, TEFAP and Resilient Food Systems Infrastructure grants—to support school meals, food banks, rural producers and food security.

Through grants and employee-match & volunteer programs, TI Foundation has donated over $6 million since 2018 to North Texas Food Bank, including a $1 million grant in June 2025 to fund 3 million meals.
NFL star Ezekiel Elliott partnered with CentreTX apparel company during COVID‑19 to sell merchandise and donate proceeds (about $85k) to the North Texas Food Bank to support hunger relief.

Catholic Charities Dallas operates both fixed-location and mobile food pantries across the Diocese of Dallas, distributing over 8 million pounds of food annually—which equates to roughly 1.2 million meals through fixed pantries and more than 5 million via mobile pantries to clients in need. Their services are open to individuals and families meeting federal poverty guidelines, SNAP recipients, and those facing temporary crises, with no paperwork required. They also coordinate food drives, in-kind donations, and partnerships with organizations like the North Texas Food Bank to provide nutritious, client-choice food options to vulnerable communities.

Bonton Farms is a South Dallas urban farm that transforms vacant land into a source of fresh, organic food and community empowerment. In addition to growing produce and raising livestock, it offers job training, nutrition education, housing support, and wellness programs to address systemic poverty and health disparities. The organization operates a café, market, and mentorship programs to help residents build stable, self-sufficient lives.

A Garland-based pantry open weekdays that provides supplemental food assistance to roughly 4,000 households monthly—including 500–600 families and unhoused individuals—offering fresh produce and pre‑packaged Weekend Bags for kids. They are a top partner of the North Texas Food Bank and have received recognition like the 2024 Retail Partner of the Year.

Organization Name: Jill Stone Community Garden at Temple Emanu‑El
Organization Description: Founded in 2012, this volunteer-run garden grows culturally relevant, organic produce (7,200 lb last year) to donate to neighborhood food pantries like Vickery Meadow, expanding with greenhouses and Master Gardener support to combat food desert challenges. It integrates community engagement, education, and the Jewish principle of tikkun olam.

Known as The Center, it serves over 500 Kaufman-area households monthly with groceries via its food pantry and SNAP assistance, plus mobile distributions, senior boxes, job/financial education, hygiene and laundry support, distributing around 320 tons of food in 2023.

A global hunger relief charity providing nutrient-rich porridge, milk, and food packages for vulnerable children and families—offering crisis support like food and housing aid in developing countries through small donations (e.g., £30 feeds a family for a month).

Created with an $85,000 grant from Hope for Tomorrow, Resource Center Health brings primary care rooms, case management offices, and trained staff into one facility. It integrates medical services with existing supports like a food pantry, pharmacy, insurance assistance, and hot meals for a more holistic approach to neighbor wellness.

Formerly Seven Loaves Food Pantry, The Storehouse now supports ~5,000 families monthly with groceries, clothing, case management, and education/job training through The Academy. Serving North Dallas and surrounding areas, it addresses invisible poverty with a full pathway from basic needs to employment readiness.

An all-volunteer, client-choice pantry serving about 180 families weekly (5,300/month) in Pleasant Grove, distributing over 2 million pounds of food since 2010. As a North Texas Food Bank Partner Agency, it leverages donations, SNAP support, and community referrals to combat food insecurity in a high-need neighborhood.

DFW Airport supports the regional food system through a robust concessions program and sustainability efforts that reduce food waste. Initiatives like composting, cooking oil recycling, and liquid disposal divert tens of thousands of pounds from landfills and convert waste into compost or renewable fuel.

Frazier Revitalization is a nonprofit established in 2005 to drive equitable community development in the historic Frazier neighborhood of South Dallas. Through partnerships with residents, the City of Dallas, and local organizations, they provide affordable housing, health access, youth education, food security, and community engagement to transform the area into a thriving, resilient neighborhood.

The Hotel Association of North Texas (HANTX) is a nonprofit trade organization representing about 44,000 rooms across six counties. It advocates for the hospitality industry, provides education and workforce development (including scholarships and training programs), facilitates networking among hotels and suppliers, and supports community engagement through volunteer initiatives.

Westin Hotels is a wellness-focused hotel brand under Marriott International, offering premium hospitality experiences designed around guest well-being. Through amenities like fitness studios and healthy menu options, it serves thousands of travelers and contributes to the food ecosystem as a high-volume institutional food purchaser.

The Chris Howell Foundation provides critical health, food, and educational resources to underserved populations in Dallas. Since 2016, it has distributed millions of pounds of food while hosting large-scale community wellness events, making it a central player in addressing food insecurity.

The Dallas Regional Chamber supports business growth and public policy across North Texas, representing thousands of local businesses and institutions. Through workforce development, regional partnerships, and advocacy, it helps shape food policy and supports food-related business growth.

The Rainwater Charitable Foundation is a Fort Worth-based private funder investing in scalable solutions to systemic challenges in education, health, and family support. It funds initiatives that improve food access, housing stability, and educational equity in local and international contexts.

Truist is a national financial institution that supports communities through banking services and philanthropic giving. It backs workforce development and food security programs through its charitable foundation, particularly in economically vulnerable areas.

The DFW Hospital Council is a nonprofit collaborative of hospitals working to improve health outcomes and workforce pipelines across the region. It plays a role in the food system by promoting patient nutrition, supporting health equity initiatives, and linking health providers to food access programs.

The Rees-Jones Foundation funds nonprofit efforts that protect and uplift vulnerable children and families, with an emphasis on access to healthcare, food, and education. It makes large-scale investments in local Dallas initiatives that improve quality of life and systemic opportunity.

Common Threads offers hands-on nutrition education and cooking programs for children and families in underserved communities. By promoting healthy eating and food literacy, it helps build community resilience and reduce long-term health disparities.

The Perot Foundation is a Dallas-based philanthropic organization with a decades-long legacy in fighting hunger through transformational gifts, including a $10.5M donation to the North Texas Food Bank that supported capital campaigns and long-term food security infrastructure.

The University of North Texas at Dallas operates hunger-relief initiatives including on-campus student food pantries and monthly mobile food giveaways in partnership with North Texas Food Bank, distributing hundreds of thousands of pounds of food to students and the surrounding southern Dallas community.

Feed Oak Cliff is a grassroots nonprofit addressing food apartheid in southern Dallas by building community-led solutions like a transformative grocery market, bistro, and commercial kitchen to expand access to fresh, affordable food in underserved neighborhoods.

An innovative startup that has a solution for eliminating food deserts profitably with e-commerce technology and community pick up locations. Nia had several pilots in the Houston area and looking at growth to Dallas at some point

The Shops at Red Bird is a revitalization project transforming a former mall in South Dallas into a mixed-use development with retail, housing, healthcare, and community spaces aimed at economic renewal.
The Hoblitzelle Foundation is a long-standing Dallas-based private philanthropic foundation funding medical research, education, arts, and social services to improve quality of life in North Texas.
The Dallas Foundation is a community foundation connecting donors with local nonprofits to address needs in arts, education, health, and economic security through grants and leadership programs.
The Addy Foundation funds regional nonprofits focused on education, healthcare, and community development, emphasizing equity and sustainable impact across the Southwestern U.S.
Children’s Medical Center Dallas is a leading pediatric hospital offering comprehensive care, specialty services, and community wellness programs for children in North Texas.
United to Learn partners with Dallas ISD elementary schools to improve literacy, student success, and community engagement through volunteers, resources, and school support.
Texas A&M University–Commerce (East Texas A&M) delivers undergraduate and graduate degree programs and supports regional growth through research, outreach, and student development.

HR&A Advisors is a national real estate and economic development consulting firm with a Dallas office, providing urban planning, policy analysis, and strategy services to build equitable, resilient communities.
Visiting Nurse Association of Texas offers home-based hospice, palliative care, and Meals on Wheels across North Texas, enabling seniors and medically vulnerable individuals to receive care at home.
Debra's Healing Kitchen is a faith-based wellness nonprofit offering nutrition education, cooking demos, workshops, and school programs to prevent chronic disease in underserved populations.
McKinsey & Company is a global management consulting firm advising corporations, governments, and nonprofits on strategy, operations, digital, and sustainability initiatives with data-driven impact.
Giving Tree Acres is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit community farm in DFW that grows fresh produce for food pantries, school markets, and farmstands in underserved neighborhoods to combat food insecurity.
Empowering the Masses empowers South Dallas residents through vocational training, life skills, health advocacy, and a Community Market to address economic and food access barriers.
Nextband Partners is a Dallas-based real estate and investment firm led by Adam Lampert, specializing in commercial development and strategic investment in the local market.
Mill City Community Association, founded in 2012 in Oak Cliff, supports neighborhood preservation and development through housing, infrastructure projects, and resident-led engagement.
Friendship-West is a Dallas megachurch with a strong social justice mission, offering ministries that include hunger relief, legal advocacy, scholarships, and community services.
Social Venture Partners Dallas is a philanthropic network that strengthens nonprofits through funding, capacity building, and collaborative impact to scale solutions in the region.

The Initiative for Energy Justice (IEJ) is a nonprofit organization focused on ensuring that the transition to clean energy is equitable and inclusive, especially for frontline and marginalized communities. Founded by lawyers of color, IEJ provides policy guidance, legal tools, and research to help communities shape just energy policies. Their work supports advocates and policymakers in embedding equity into renewable energy planning and decision-making.

Organization Name: Stacey D. Brown Coaching and Consulting
Organization Description: Stacey D. Brown is a Dallas-based mental health coach, ordained minister, and wellness consultant supporting spiritual leaders and nonprofits. She focuses on trauma-informed care, burnout recovery, and leadership development through coaching, workshops, and speaking engagements.

Share Our Strength is a national nonprofit organization working to end hunger and poverty in the United States and abroad. It is best known for its No Kid Hungry campaign, which focuses on ensuring all children have reliable access to nutritious food. The organization partners with community groups, advocates for public policy, and provides grants and support to local initiatives.

NorthPark Presbyterian Church is a long-established Dallas congregation with a strong mission orientation. It operates innovative initiatives like the Reverse Food Truck—a mobile food drive—and the SoulFood Greenhouse, which yields thousands of pounds of pesticide-free produce annually for Vickery Meadow Food Pantry and other hunger relief partners. Through these and other outreach programs, the church mobilizes volunteers and community support to combat food insecurity across North Dallas.

Miles of Freedom is a Dallas-based nonprofit that empowers individuals, families, and communities impacted by incarceration through reentry programs, employment training, and a no-barrier fresh produce distribution pantry. Since 2019, their MLK Fresh Produce Distribution Center has served all neighbors, distributing over 2 million pounds of food—thanks in part to a capacity grant from North Texas Food Bank. Their holistic model bridges gaps from prison to promise by combining life-skills support with sustainable community food access.  ￼ ￼ ￼ ￼

The Dallas County Inland Port Transportation Management Association (IPTMA) is a nonprofit organization formed in 2019 to enhance transportation access within the 120-square-mile Southern Dallas Inland Port region. It collaborates with employers, local governments, and transit agencies like DART and Uber to provide services such as GoLink and Inland Port Rides, addressing last-mile connectivity for workers. Additionally, IPTMA organizes annual symposia to foster dialogue on workforce development and infrastructure planning.

New Friends New Life is a Dallas nonprofit that supports survivors of trafficking and sexual exploitation through trauma-informed care, education, and job training. They operate resource centers for youth and adults and offer urban agriculture apprenticeships to help clients rebuild their lives. The organization also focuses on prevention and community awareness.

M.E.L. INC. Foundation (Manage * Elevate * Lead) is a Dallas-based nonprofit founded in 2014 by Mel Jackson to support underserved communities through programs focused on domestic violence, education, and health & nutrition. Initially launched as Mended Hearts Mentoring Program (MHMP), the organization provides career coaching, community partnerships, and personal development resources to empower individuals and strengthen neighborhoods.  ￼

Community Lifeline Center is a nonprofit based in McKinney serving North Collin County, founded in 1989 by local churches to provide food and emergency assistance to families in crisis. It operates a client-choice grocery-style pantry, weekly mobile food distributions, and offers financial aid for rent and utilities to help prevent homelessness. In 2025, the organization served over 100,000 individuals and continues expanding its pantry services and community partnerships.
A grouping of organizations that collect, store, and redistribute donated or surplus food to nonprofits, pantries, and individuals in need.
A grouping of various locally focused farms that prioritize community involvement, education, and access over profit, often using sustainable practices.
A grouping of facilities that prepare and sell meat products, often sourcing from farms or processors for local distribution.
A grouping of establishments that prepare and serve meals directly to consumers, often sourcing ingredients from various parts of the supply chain.

Recycle Revolution is a locally owned recycling and composting company in Dallas focused on sustainable waste solutions. They offer commercial and residential pickup services, operate a public drop-off center, and work to promote zero-waste practices across the community. Their mission centers on environmental responsibility and community engagement.
Families from South Dallas receiving food.

The Comet Cupboard is a student-run food pantry providing perishable and non-perishable food along with personal care items to UT Dallas students. It operates as part of a service-learning initiative, serving thousands of students annually and offering volunteer leadership opportunities.

Located in the Eco Hub, Luna Farm is a 20,000 sq ft student-led micro-farm and sustainability living lab launched in fall 2021. It uses organic practices to grow fresh produce and maintain an apiary, donating 100% of its harvest to address student food insecurity through the Comet Cupboard.
Patients in the Parkland Health Center

Brother Bill’s Helping Hand (BBHH) is a nonprofit serving West Dallas since the 1940s, offering a grocery-style food pantry, community health clinic, and educational programs. It provides free primary care, job training, and after-school activities to support families in need. BBHH also co-leads the South Dallas Community Market to increase access to fresh food and wraparound services.

A 501(c)(3) nonprofit event celebrating Texas culture, agriculture, education, and community through its annual 24-day Fair at Fair Park. It draws over 2 million visitors each year and reinvests proceeds into maintaining Fair Park, scholarships, community grants, and educational initiatives.  ￼

Founded in 1873, this professional nonprofit supports Dallas lawyers and promotes connections among the legal community, judiciary, and public. It focuses on legal education, ethics, community service, and access to justice initiatives.  ￼

The philanthropic arm of Energy Transfer LP and Sunoco, that provides grants and supports causes in education, healthcare, hunger relief, veterans, and first responders. In Texas, it has donated to MD Anderson Cancer Hospital, Mercy Street sports ministry, Salvation Army, and regional food banks.  ￼

Blue Meridian Partners is a philanthropic investment collaborative focused on transforming the lives of people living in poverty across the U.S. By pooling resources from large-scale donors, it funds both national initiatives and place-based strategies—like Dallas’s Opportunity 2040—that aim to create lasting economic mobility and address systemic barriers. Their model emphasizes long-term, flexible funding to support scalable, data-driven solutions.

Goodr is a tech-enabled logistics company that helps businesses reduce edible food waste by redirecting surplus meals and groceries to underserved communities via a blockchain-tracked system. Operating a model that supports sustainability and social impact, Goodr provides free grocery access in partnership with corporate and public sector clients.

Imperfect Foods is an online grocery delivery service that rescues cosmetically imperfect or surplus food from farms and manufacturers, selling it at discounted prices to subscribers. The service promotes sustainability and affordability by reducing food waste and providing flexible, customizable delivery options.

Misfits Market is a subscription-based grocery delivery company that sources so-called “ugly” or surplus produce and pantry items—often rejected by traditional grocery retailers—and delivers them directly to consumers at lower cost. It acquired Imperfect Foods in 2022 and continues to expand its reach in reducing food system waste.

Joppy Momma’s Farm is a Dallas nonprofit community farm in the historic Joppa neighborhood founded to rebuild and uplift a former freedmen’s settlement. The organization focuses on sustainable agriculture, growing fresh produce to combat food insecurity, and provides educational and economic opportunities to local families.

Divert is a U.S.-based impact-tech company focused on reducing food waste through a circular economy model—Prevent, Provide, Power™. Serving over 6,600 retail locations nationwide, it uses RFID tracking, logistics, and anaerobic digestion technologies to redirect unsold food to communities in need and convert waste into renewable energy. As of 2024, Divert had processed over 3.3 billion pounds of food, facilitated millions of meals, and continues scaling with new infrastructure investments.

Aldi is a fast-growing discount grocery chain in the U.S., known for low prices and a no-frills shopping experience. It operates over 2,400 stores nationwide and is expanding rapidly, including a significant presence in the Dallas area. With plans to open hundreds of new locations, Aldi is becoming a major player in affordable grocery retail across North Texas.

The U.S. Food Waste Pact is a national voluntary agreement, led by ReFED and WWF, that brings food businesses together to commit to reducing waste using the “Target, Measure, Act” framework. With quarterly working groups and pilot initiatives, signatories share data, benchmark progress, and scale interventions across the supply chain. It builds on the success of the Pacific Coast Food Waste Commitment and now includes major retailers and industry associations.

Sodexo provides food services to institutions across Dallas such as hospitals, universities, and corporate campuses. Their local operations feature sustainable menu planning, donation of surplus meals, and implementation of waste-tracking systems to reduce food loss and support community-facing food recovery efforts.

Whole Foods operates at least eight stores in the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex, including key locations in Uptown Dallas and Plano. These stores host community food rescue efforts, surplus giveaways, and support local producers through in-store partnerships, cooking demos, and local vendor showcase initiatives.

Amazon Fresh grocery services—including online orders and select physical pickup locations—serve the Dallas area, offering mass-market pricing competitive with traditional grocers. Their operations include discounting near-expiration items, grocery delivery, and partnerships integrated with delivery zones covering Dallas and Fort Worth.

Aramark is a global food service provider that operates in schools, universities, hospitals, and businesses across the U.S., including in the Dallas area. The company manages cafeteria services, catering, and on-site dining programs while also implementing sustainability initiatives like reducing food waste and sourcing responsibly. In Dallas, Aramark partners with local institutions to deliver consistent, large-scale food operations that support both daily consumption and event-based services.

Starbucks is a multinational coffeehouse chain known for serving coffee, beverages, and light food items in over 35,000 locations worldwide. In Dallas, it operates numerous retail stores that offer dine-in, drive-thru, and mobile ordering services, forming a prominent part of the city’s quick-service food and beverage landscape. The company also integrates retail sales of packaged goods and branded merchandise through its stores.

Grocery Connect—operated in partnership with Bonton Farms, Kroger Delivery, and community centers—is an online grocery ordering and fee‑free pickup service serving underserved neighborhoods in South Dallas. It currently operates staffed pickup hubs at ICDC (serving Frazier and Mill City) and the Dallas Bethlehem Center, complemented by concierge support, SNAP/EBT assistance, healthy meal planning, and cooking education to improve access and nutrition in local food deserts.

VolunteerNow is the leading volunteer mobilization hub in North Texas, coordinating over 300,000 volunteers annually and generating significant impact through its proprietary VOLY.org platform, which serves schools, nonprofits, courts, and corporations. They operate a robust Donated Goods program—including Discount Depot storefronts, Goods Giveaways, and Goods Grants—that redistributes essential items to low- and moderate-income communities across DFW. Additionally, they provide key services such as community service restitution, background checks, volunteer manager training, and corporate volunteer activation.
